title: tv-review-would-you-adam-and-eve-who-turned-up-on-the-square
story: But stone the bleedinrsquo crows and lsquoave a bananathe writers didnrsquot push the boat out for the showrsquos th birthday by bringing back some of the original characters. And they werenrsquot even dead or nuffink!Well, one of them was. Dr Legg, recently brought back into the fray, was being laid to rest, and there to pay their respects were Mary and Lofty.Now, come on, you remember them. Among the ways of finding out a personrsquos age, apart from cutting them in half and counting the ringsis to ask who their favourite EastEnder character is. If they say Mary the punk, or Lofty the big drink of water, they are definitely middle- aged.The day of the funeral dawned with curtains being drawn in only one of the houses in the Square. No-one holds with the old conventions now. Over in the market, Martin Fowler, who has had more faces than Ian Beale has had wives, was telling someone that Dr Legg had been a friend of his gran, Lou. Across the country, a lot of people suddenly felt very old.This being EastEnders there had to be some drama over the funeral. Dot, one of Dr Leggrsquos oldest friends, was due to read at the service but she was out of sorts. "I can barely get a cuppa tea down her", said Sonia, which in EastEnders is the equivalent of a hospital code blue.Just as Dr Leggrsquos soap le was being brought to a close another was starting, with the arrival of Masoodrsquos sparky nieces. They asked someone what time the restaurant opened. Sorry, havenrsquot been here for years, said a smartly dressed lady with a peroxide pixie crop. Mary!Mary had a grown up daughter with her , as did Sonia. Must have been a BOGOF offer at the Minute Mart.Next old face to turn up was Lofty who now owns  pubs. "All well away from here," he tells Sharon. Well, obviously. Dangerous game running a pub in those parts. He asks after his ex, Michelle, who is off travelling. In reality, Michelle, played by Susan Tully, became a successful director and producer. Since wersquore catching up, Tom Wattmakes films for BT Sport, and ghost-wrote David Beckhamrsquos autobiography, while Linda Davidsonis something big in on-line ops.Down the Queen Vic after the service, Mary had a dig at Dot for calling her parents and telling them to take baby Annie away. Dot reminded Mary that she also told her to steer clear of Pat, who wanted to put Mary on the game. Pat as a madam. It was a reminder of how dark EastEnders once was, albeit in a grim down south, Loachian way. These days it too often plumps for sensationalism, and is much less effective.Cathy lightened the mood by reminding everyone of the hilarious time Dr Legg caught Loursquos bedcover in his bag and walked off, trailing it behind him. Sadly, that is what passes as comedy in EastEnders.The half hour almost up, Lofty gave Martin a cheque for lsquoChellersquos daughter, Vicky, the one he thought was his but was really Dirty Denrsquos . Everyone piled outside, only to see all the houses in the square had their curtains closed as a mark of respect. Nothing had changed in the East End, after all. Cue the drums...

title: kirsty-hughes-the-uk-needs-to-step-back-from-brexit-and-mend-its-broken-politics
story: Theresa May clings on to her Brexit chariot as it careers downhill, her party and Government powerless and fractured but somehow beaten to its inevitable split by Chuka Ummuna and his gang. EU leaders look on aghast as Mrs May continues her forlorn ring-round to get unlikely changes to the Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile Jeremy Corbyn resists either backing Mrs Mayrsquos deal or supporting the Peoplersquos Vote that Labour voters and members want. A left-wing, pro-EU  could potentially garner big support in the polls, but Mr Corybn puts ideology ahead of political gains.Damaging uncertainty reigns with all outcomes still possible on Brexit: a no-deal chaotic Brexit, Mrs Mayrsquos hard but unclear Brexit, a compromise May-Corbyn Brexit , an extension to Article  or no Brexit at all.There is a triple stand-off going on, amidst this dishonest political posturing, between the executive, the legislature and the people. Theresa May looks powerless but is still standing despite the Commons rejecting her deal by  votes, her then backing the Brady amendment against her own deal , then losing again last Thursday by  votes as the hard Brexiters feared she was backing the Commons rejection of no deal.Yet Mrs May keeps running down the clock, desperately searching for a majority to carry the UK over the Brexit line. Mr Corbyn provides no serious opposition. Various smaller groupings in the Commons attempt to stop her while disagreeing on what should happenthey succeed. Government, opposition and the legislature as a whole are in the midst of a damaging breakdown.Meanwhile, the much-hyped ldquopeople are essentially ignored. The trope that the Commons is pro-Remain, reluctant to implement the ldquowill of the people, is simply wrong. There is a Remain majority across the UK , even in England. Yet the two main political parties, and most of their MPs, keep supporting Brexit but with no consensus still on what Brexit actually means.This is a deep democratic and political failure. Brexit is damaging our economy, our devolution settlement, our security and has trashed the UKrsquos international reputation. And yet the views of the - per cent of the public who now support Remain are not represented at this critical moment by the UKrsquos two main parties. In Scotland ndash and in the Commons ndash the SNP and the LibDems support Remain and another vote but, so far, to little effect, even with the support of Labour and Tory rebels. And Mrs Mayrsquos government has been shockingly ready to let Northern Irelandrsquos lack of executive and assembly drag on.Hoping to stop a no-deal Brexit, Yvette Cooper is putting forward a cross-party amendment next week to demand an Article  delay. She doesnrsquot say how long or what for ndash both things the EU will surely demand to know since they must agree any delay unanimously. But her amendment must lack clarity to have a chance of passing.Another amendment from Labour MPs Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson suggests the Commons back Mrs Mayrsquos deal on the condition of another referendum. Itrsquos a rather tawdry politics that needs MPs to vote for something they oppose to get something, a Peoplersquos Vote, they could just vote directly for.If Ms Cooper succeeds, Mrs May would have to pass her deal by mid-March or request an Article  extension rather than chasing a reckless las- minute Commons vote after the EUrsquos March  summit. Yet, whether in mid- or end-March, the EU could reject delay, or set unpalatable conditions. Or the EU might tell the UK to go away for a year and sort out its political breakdown .Read more: Brexit Day still March  insists GovernmentMeanwhile, dferent groups that oppose Brexit still play into Mrs Mayrsquos timetable. The Peoplersquos Vote campaign have called for a big demonstration on March  which only makes senseBrexit decisions are dangerously delayed until three days before Brexit.Nicola Sturgeon too keeps delaying any decision on another independence referendum. She is waiting for a clear Brexit outcome, something our failing politics looks unlikely to deliver. A chaotic no-deal or a fudged delay will not clary the options for future UK-Scotland relations but either may sharply intensy the independence debate. The Scottish Government must either take a decision amidst uncertainty or embrace the politics of delay too.Brexit shows clearly that the UKrsquos politics is broken and desperately needs modernising. A written constitution and proportional representation for Westminster voting would be a good start. The two big parties need to splitand England has work to do on its own identity and regional politics.And the UK should step back from Brexit so it can start to mend its politics without its economy, security and reputation going down the drain in parallel. Amidst such political and constitutional renewal, the UK could exploretherersquos a new federal model that could work while offering Scotland the chance to decideit wants to break away or be part of that renewal ndash and letting Northern Ireland,it wants, hold a border poll.Yet listing these basic modernisation steps underlines how unlikely they are and how far UK politics is from rescuing itself. Brexit is not the only cause of the UKrsquos political implosion but itrsquos the main immediate trigger. And careering towards a damaging, possibly no-deal Brexit will only intensy that political collapse.Brexit might yet be halted, whether through revoking Article  or holding a successful Peoplersquos Vote. If so, the long, hard work of political renewal could possibly begin. But it wonrsquot be quick or easy.Five weeks before the Brexit deadline, the UK is dependent on its powerless Government and a ided Westminster to rescue itself from this ever deeper crisis. It might happen. But donrsquot bet on the failing heart of a failing system riding to its own rescue.* The author is director of the Scottish Centre on European Relations.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: letters-exodus-of-manufacturers-highlights-the-folly-of-brexit
story: Ironically, the EU-Japan deal has just come into force and the Japanese can now export directly into the EU and vice-versa.At present, the Honda factory in Swindon exports the Civic even to Japan, so globally within the EU it was performing well.The announcement is another reminder that the UK car industry ndash or rather the English car industry, as all factories are based in England ndash is a misnomer. Ownership and investment funding, a great deal of research and development, and control and decision-making largely come from outwith the country. Even iconic, quintessentially English brands Rolls-Royce and Bentley are German-owned and Jaguar Land Rover is owned by Tata of India, India once the Jewel in the Crown of the British Empire.The ironies abound in this Brexit saga to date. But when people in the areas where there areforeign and EU car companies established because of direct access to exports to the single market, voted to leave one must question the wisdom of such people. The predominance of that vote drags Scotland out of the EU against its democratic vote to remain in .The decisions by Renault-Nissan and Honda are just the start of a move-out and added to the likes of UK-based Sir James Dyson and Sir James Ratclfe deciding to sht as well do not augur well at all.North of the Tweed, the insular, cringeworthy, wee crabbit Unionist branch parties criticise the First Minister leading a trade delegation from Scotland to France, Scotlandrsquos third-largest export market, to promote technology companiesone wondersthey too are infected by a ldquoBritish-itis mindset Nicola Sturgeon will address Francersquos Foreign Affairs Committee and open the Scottish Governmentrsquos France Hub. By creating open contact and cementing a new ldquoAuld Alliance via Holyrood, one sees clearly that positive outward and open links are being established which will bring not only benefits but more signicantly good will for the future.John Edgar,a Langmuir Quadrant, Kilmaurs.SO, following her US trip, Nicola Sturgeon visits France on what is billed, at least in part, to be a trade mission. If thatrsquos the case, then maybe fair enough itrsquos not unusual for non-Westminster politicians to travel in an attempt to boost trade for the part of the UK for which they have some responsibility.But let us remember the rest of the UK is by far Scotlandrsquos largest ldquoexport market. Why is Ms Sturgeon not also visiting ious parts of England, Wales and Northern Ireland to grow yet further our signicant trade with where in the UK  Were she to do so, it might help deflect criticism that she has little interest in strengthening ties with the rest of the UK ndash and that she uses her trade mission trips to talk down the UK and talk up her own separatist agenda.Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.IT wont be long til the complete folly of Brexit is brought down on all of us, Leavers and Remainers the same, and fishers, farmers, financiers and whoever  fell for all the utter blarney of it, are wringing their hands and blaming everybody .Already the farmers, admittedly not avid Brexiters, are sending out serious labour shortage distress signals, and it cannot be long til fishers, some very avid Brexiters among them, will be lamenting like mythic mermaids not only a dearth of foreign filleters but the drastic delays in getting their fish to their established European consumers. Sending fish to America, Asia, and Australia isnt as assured as sending it fresh to Paris.The old Scots saying, "Neer cast a cloot til May be oot" aptly applies to the UK leader of that name in this instance. Alas oor cloots already appear to be cast long before the month of May.Ian Johnstone, Forman Drive, Peterhead.WHILE ploughing through Ian Lakinrsquos letter , I came across the following excerpts: ldquohellip unless they can coherently explain the economic case for independence they are going nowherehellip. He also claims ldquonow is the time for them to accept the democratic will of the Scottish people.In the first place as the UK launched into Brexit as an ill-advised, ill-judged and ill-negotiated exercise, with a loss of investment, jobs, industries and a total shambles of the UK as a whole, he is in no position to lecture Scotland as he has done. As to the ldquodemocratic will of the Scottish people, we voted  per cent to remain and  per cent to leave.It seems to me he is flying a mouldy kite to distract attention from the appalling and insoluble bourach his politacl leaders have got us into.Britain will be devouring a very large piece of humble pie, but unfortunately Scotland will be given a large share.Jim Lynch, Corstorphine Hill Crescent, Edinburgh.THERE is no such thing as Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal. The Withdrawal Agreementis merely a legal contract to pay pound billion, in exchange for which the UK secures a transition with no veto rights, and is bound to accept all fresh EU law.On payment of the exit fee the UK also secure the lsquorsquoprivilegersquorsquo of starting talks on a deal. But, unlike the WA, the terms of that deal must be agreed by all  EU states. As experience to date has shown, this will be a negotiating nightmare. Wersquoll face the same clf-edge in two years, but with less leverage and with unanimity to contend with. In a report the House of Lords has said the UK could walk away from the EU in  without paying a penny.No matter what the PM says now, in order to get any trade deal, the UK will end up having to accept the single market for goods and the customs union, freedom of movement, fishery quotas, and the writ of the European Court. title: westminster-ignores-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-tells-french-parliament
story: An independent Scotland would seek to be a "close ally" of other European nations, in contrast to the "isolationism that characterises Brexit" she claimed.The First Minister saidScotland was to leave the UK "independence would see us recognising and embracing our interdependence with other nations".She told an audience at the Assemblee Nationale in the French Parliament that the two years since the UKs vote to leave the European Union had "underlined the importance" of that.The SNP leader has pledged to make public her thoughts on the possible timing of any second Scottish independence referendum in the coming weeks.:Agonies of Brexit could break-up Britain, says Sir John MajorAs she addressed members of the French Parliaments foreign affairs committee, she was clear Scotland should "have the option to choose a dferent course by opting to become an independent country" when there is "greater clarity about the terms of Brexit".Ms Sturgeon said: "I will say more about independence at a future date."One thing I do want to stress, however, is that for the Scottish Government, independence is not about the isolationism that characterises Brexit - instead independence would see us recognising and embracing our interdependence with other nations."We will always seek to be close allies and partners with our neighbours in Europe."The last two years, to my mind, have underlined the importance of that position."The First Minister repeated her calls for the UK to hold a second vote on Brexit, with the option of remaining in the EU to be on the ballot paper.She said: "There is a strong democratic case for that. For Parliament, it is a way to break the deadlock."For Scotland, it is an opportunity for our wish to stay in the EU to be respected."And for all voters, it is a chance to make a decision based on much more detailed information than was ever made available in ."A lack of information at the time of the European referendum allowed Brexiteers to portray the EU as a "scapegoat" for wider concerns about austerity and inequality, Ms Sturgeon said.She said: "At the time of the referendum, people who opted to leave knew that they were voting against EU membership but they did not know what they were voting for."That allowed the EU to serve as a scapegoat for wider concerns - for example, an entirely justied dissatisfaction about austerity, inequality and stagnant living standards.:, Scots face losing their job due to no-deal Brexit, MSPs told"A second vote could be based on a much clearer understanding of what the leave option actually means in practice."She conceded there is no majority for a second Brexit referendum in the UK Parliament at present but said this "remains one way out of the problems the UK has created for itself".As a result of this, the First Minister added: "It is a course the Scottish Government will support."We cannot endorse the UK Governments current Brexit proposals and we will do everything in our power to secure a better outcome for Scotland, the UK and Europe."

title: brexit-theresa-may-to-return-to-brussels-to-seek-legal-assurances-over-backstop
story: Chancellor Philip Hammond indicated on Tuesday night that the Government has accepted the EU will not agree to replace the backstop arrangements for the Irish border with technological alternatives in time for the scheduled date of Brexit on March .:, Scots face losing their job due to no-deal Brexit, MSPs toldBut he said he hopes the technological solution contained in the so-called Malthouse Compromise will form part of negotiations over the following  months on the UKs future relationship with the EU.After being briefed on developments in private talks with the PM, leading Brexiteers Jacob Rees-Mogg and Steve Baker appeared happy with this arrangement, declaring that the Malthouse proposals were "alive and kicking".Mr Baker said it was now possible that Tory eurosceptics in the influential European Research Group, of which he is deputy chair, would back Mrs Mays Withdrawal Agreement, after helping to vote it down by a massive margin last month."Im hopeful that as the conversation moves forward with the EU and with the UK that we might get to a position where we can vote for the Withdrawal Agreement," said Mr Baker."Its a very big journey from here to there. Im very grateful that today we took a big step on that journey by the general acceptance that these arrangements could work."In a joint statement, Mr Baker and ERG chair Mr Rees-Mogg said: "We look forward to further precision about exactly what we will be asked to vote for."Mr Hammond told the MakeUK dinner in London that the proposals in the Malthouse plan - drawn up by MPs from the Leave and Remain wings of the party - represented a "valuable effort" at finding a way to keep the Irish border open after Brexit without a backstop.But the Chancellor said: "However promising as an alternative arrangement to avoid entering a backstop in the future, it is clear that the EU will not consider replacing the backstop with such an alternative arrangement now in order to address our immediate challenge.:EU not prepared to re-open the Withdrawal Agreement ahead of Theresa May visit"The details of this initiative are still evolving and would require signicant changes to EU legislation and customs practices that would need to be negotiated with the EU member states and others who will be affected by them."He added: "It should be a major ongoing strand of our work, continuing at pace during the Implementation Period - one in which I hope and expect the EU will take an active part."The developments came as Mrs May prepared for a crucial meeting with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels.Mr Juncker has said that he does not expect a "breakthrough" in talks at which Mrs May is expected to request legally-binding assurances that the backstop will not extend indefinitely.She believes that this is the key to winning the support of the House of Commons for her deal, and seeing off efforts to extend the negotiation period in a series of votes expected on February ."I have great respect for Theresa May, for her courage and her assertiveness," Mr Juncker said during a visit to Germany. "We will have friendly talks tomorrow but I dont expect a breakthrough."Mr Hammond said that legally-binding changes to ensure the backstop does not become permanent "would deliver the core of a majority for a deal in the House of Commons".He told the MakeUK dinner: "Our priority remains avoiding a No Deal outcome, and that will be my unwavering focus."It is clear that leaving the EU without a deal would deliver a damaging short-term shock and would undermine our future prosperity and security - and in my view that would represent a betrayal of the promises about Brexit that were made during the referendum campaign."So the solution lies in getting the PMs deal through Parliament."A senior adviser to EU negotiator Michel Barnier said there was "zero appetite" in the capitals of the  remaining members to renegotiate the agreement reached with the UK last November."The ideas for reopening the Withdrawal Agreement are basically for changing the backstop and making it no longer a genuine backstop, because a backstop has to be there whatever the circumstances," Stefaan de Rynck told the UK in a Changing Europe think tank in London."If you have a time limit or a unilateral exit clause, you no longer have a genuine backstop. So there is zero appetite in the EU to reopen that Withdrawal Agreement."The backstop arrangements would see the whole UK remain in a customs union with the EU and Northern Ireland following some single market rules until a wider trade deal is agreed, in order to prevent the need for checkpoints on the Irish border.The Malthouse plan would replace these arrangements with technological methods for tracking cross-border movements, along with a free trade agreement-lite for Northern Ireland.If this was not acceptable to Brussels, a Plan B would see the UK leave without a deal but with a transition period extended to the end of  to allow time to prepare.After talks on the Malthouse plan between Mr Barnier and Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay on Monday, Mr Barclays Department for Exiting the EU said: "While the Commission engaged seriously with these proposals, it expressed concerns about their viability to resolve the backstop."We agreed to keep exploring the use of alternative arrangements - especially how they might be developed to ensure the absence of a hard border in Northern Ireland on a permanent footing, avoiding the need for the backstop to ever enter force."

title: in-full-resignation-letter-of-anna-soubry-sarah-wollaston-and-heidi-allen
story: Here is their resignation letter in full:Dear Prime MinsterIt is with regret that we are writing to resign the Conservative whip and our membership of the Party.:Funding blow for breakaway MP groupWe voted for you as Leader and Prime Minister because we believed you were committed to a moderate, open-hearted Conservative Party in the One Nation tradition. A party of economic competence, representing the best of British business, delivering good jobs, opportunity and prosperity for all, funding world class public services and tackling inequalities. We had hoped you would also continue to modernise our party so that it could reach out and broaden its appeal to younger voters and to embrace and reflect the ersity of the communities we seek to represent.BREAKING: Sarah Wollaston, Heidi Allen and Anna Soubry quit Conservative Party for Independence Group https:t.co jnKjgnjISadly, the Conservative Party has increasingly abandoned these principles and values with a sht to the right of British Politics. We no longer feel we can remain in the Party of a Government whose policies and priorities are so firmly in the grip of the ERG and DUP.Brexit has re-defined the Conservative Party - undoing all the efforts to modernise it. There has been a dismal failure to stand up to the hard line ERG which operates openly as a party within a party, with its own leader, whip and policy.:Sarah Wollaston, Heidi Allen and Anna Soubry quit Conservative Party for Independence GroupThis sht to the right has been exacerbated by blatant entryism. Not only has this been tolerated, it has been actively welcomed in some quarters. A purple momentum is subsuming the Conservative Party, much as the hard left has been allowed to consume and terminally undermine the Labour Party.We have tried consistently and for some time to keep the Party close to the centre ground of British Politics. You assured us when you first sought the leadership that this was your intention. We havent changed, the Conservative Party has and it no longer reflects the values and beliefs we share with millions of people throughout the United Kingdom.The final straw for us has been this Governments disastrous handling of Brexit.Following the EU referendum of , no genuine effort was made to build a cross-party, let alone a national consensus to deliver Brexit. Instead of seeking to heal the isions or to tackle the underlying causes of Brexit, the priority was to draw up "red lines". The % were not only sidelined, they were alienated.:Joan Ryan MP outlines reasons for ditching Labour for new Independence GroupWe find it unconscionable that a Party once trusted on the economy, more than any other, is now recklessly marching the country to the clf edge of no deal. No responsible government should knowingly and deliberately inflict the dire consequences of such a destructive exit on iniduals, communities and businesses and put at risk the prospect of ending austerity.We also reject the  binary choice that you have presented to Parliament between a bad deal and no deal. Running down the clock to March  amounts to a policy of no deal and we are not prepared to wait until our toes are at the edge of the clf.We can no longer act as bystanders.We intend to sit as independents alongside The Independent Group of MPs in the centre ground of British politics. There will be times when we will support the Government, for example, on measures to strengthen our economy, security and improve our public services. But we now feel honour bound to put our constituents and countrys interests first.We would like to thank all those who have supported us and worked alongside us within our constituencies over many years. We genuinely wish our many friends and colleagues within the Party well, indeed we know many of them share our concerns.We will continue to work constructively, locally and nationally, on behalf of our constituents.However, the country deserves better. We believe there is a failure of politics in general, not just in the Conservative Party but in both main parties as theymove to the fringes, leaving millions of people with no representation. Our politics needs urgent and radical reform and we are determined to play our part.Yours sincerelyHeidi Allen, Anna Soubry and Sarah Wollaston

title: who-are-the-three-mps-who-have-resigned-from-the-conservative-party
story: Anna Soubry, Sarah Wollaston and Heidi Allen announced their defection in a joint statement via Twitter. They stated in a letter to the Prime Minister that "Brexit has remdashdefined the Conservative Party mdash undoing all the efforts to modernise it."The Remainer Conservatives made the dramatic move on Wednesday, joining former Labour Party colleagues Chuka Umunna and Luciana Berger who announced their resignation on Monday.Sarah WollastonDr Sarah Wollaston. Credit: PAThe Conservative Party member for Totnes in Devon and chair of the Health and Social Care Select Committee and the Liason Commitee in the House of Commons is a former GP who entered politics in .An outspoken Pro-Euro politician, Dr Wollaston warned members of her own party this week that their move towards a hardline stance on Brexit risked alienatingmoderate voters, saying:"there will be nothing left at all to appeal to moderate centre ground voters."Her comments heightened speculation that she would be one of a new wave of MPs who would defect to the newly formed breakaway group.Heidi AllenHeidi Allen. Credit: PAMP for South Cambridgeshire, Ms Allen was another member expected to join the ranks of the newly-formed party after her social media activity hinted at her future.On Monday she shared an article co-written by her, Jo Swinson andThangam Debbonaire on a new cross-party campaign.An MP since , Ms Allen has been a strong advocate of remining in the EU, calling for a Peoples Vote over Brexit.Anna SoubryAnna Soubry. Credit: PAThe Rt Hon Anna Soubry has beenthe member for Broxtowe in Nottinghamshire since  and has held signicant positions in Parliament since  includingMinister of State for Defence Personnel, Welfare and Veterans andMinister for Small Business, Industry and Enterprise.The fomer barrister and journalist has a reputation in the House of Commons for speaking her mind.In January she was verbally abused outside the Houses of Parliament by yellow vest protestors who branded MsSoubry a "Nazi" during a television interview.During the Article  debate in March , Ms Soubry spoke on the importance of keeping options open when it came Brexit negotiations. She has been a staunch campaigner for a second referendum on Theresa Mays proposed Brexit Deal.

title: david-mundell-very-clear-about-implications-of-no-deal-brexit-for-scotland
story: His comments during Commons Scotland questions came in response to SNP Tommy Sheppard Edinburgh East who asked: "Did he request the Prime Minister to take no deal off the table and what was her response "Mr Sheppard added: "When it comes to the matter of principle of having a deal or not is he prepared to stay in this Cabinet and implement a no deal scenario "Read more:Westminster ignores Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon tells French ParliamentMr Mundell said: "Im very clear about the implications of no deal for Scotland and the UK and thats why I want the Prime Minister to achieve a deal."He added: "I am in the deal column, I voted for the deal in the meaningful vote and I will do so again."SNP Patrick Grady Glasgow North called on Mr Mundell to "rule out a no-deal clf-edge Brexit by extending Article ".Mr Mundell said: "Theres one sure and clear way to avoid a no-deal Brexit and that is to vote for the Prime Ministers deal, but on every occasion, every occasion that the SNP have had to do that, they have declined.Read more:, Scots face losing their job due to no-deal Brexit, MSPs told"And indeed what they have sought to do is to bring a no-deal Brexit closer to reality."Responding to Mr Grady, he added: "I share his pleasure at so many present on those benches."

title: unite-calls-for-scottish-councils-to-reject-workplace-parking-levy
story: Unite has written to the  local authorities, calling on them to pledge not to bring in the controversial tax.The parking levy, proposed in the budget deal agreed between the SNP and Scottish Greens, would give councils the power to introduce a charge on workplace car parking.:SNPs car parking levy may be worthy but is it workable If introduced, the scheme would see employers pay an annual fee to the council for every parking space they provide for workers. Employers could then decide to pass on the cost to their staff.Although environmental groups have welcomed the plan as a way to encourage people to use public transport and cut emissions, critics have condemned it for "taxing workers for turning up to work".In the letter to councils, Unites Scottish secretary Pat Rafferty urged them to oppose the devolution of the levy and rule out implementing the "regressive" policy.Mr Rafferty condemned the lack of consultation over the plan, and said: "The ability for councils to set a workplace levy through car parking spaces is a desperate attempt to absolve the Government from the funding crisis they have presided over.:Tories claim GPs face pound.m parking tax bill"If implemented, we would have the ludicrous situation where we would have local authorities taxing workers for turning up to work."This would remove the pay increase that workers are currently fighting for off of them in an instance."We believe that the Scottish Government should be facilitating public ownership of the nations buses and rail network, which would be a far better way to reduce car journeys through the provision of regular and affordable travel in Scotland."

title: pmqs-jeremy-corbyn-and-theresa-may-finally-unite-over-something
story: Yet today both party leaders seemed to unite over an unspoken understanding: they would both go the entirety of PMQs without mentioning the turbulence currently rippling through Westminster.Amid simmering tensions over leadership, Brexit and antisemitism claims, Mr Corbyn and Mrs May avoided a tit-for-tat argument over whose party is more in crisis by choosing to avoid the subject entirely.Instead PMQs pressed on with a damp squibsquabbleover Brexit, leaving an elephant in the room and palpable tension on the back benches.Read more:Sarah Wollaston, Heidi Allen and Anna Soubry quit Conservative Party for Independent GroupJeremy Corbyn accused Mrs May of "pretending to negotiate" as she insisted her priority was "finding a solution" to the controversial Irish backstop.He asked exactly what Mrs May hoped to achieve by travelling to Brussels, with the Prime Ministerrsquos response being the verbal equivalent of a tumbleweed.Mr Corbyn pressed on, raising the concerns of manufacturers over the governmentrsquos refusal to take no deal off the table.Mrs May dodged accusations that she was trying to leave without a deal, and repeated that the best way to avoid a no-deal Brexit is to vote for the deal on the table.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford waded in, accusing Westminster of "being at war with itself" and telling the Prime Minister: "If you dont act, Scotland will."But the process felt frustratingly familiar as both leaders failed to ignore the  MPs who have quit their respective parties to stand as independents.The only mention of recent resignations came as Mrs May acknowledged Brighton Labour councillor Anne Meadows, who quit Labour to join the Tories, citing months of bullying and antisemitism.Read more:Jeremy Corbyn brushes off calls for change to his leadership as Labour embroiled in fresh anti-Semitism rowShe said: "Thatrsquos the harsh reality that decent moderate Labour councillors are having to face everyday, due to Jeremy Corbynrsquos failure to stand up to bullying and racism in his party."We will welcome her with open arms into the Conservative party. Irsquom sure she will be an excellent Conservative councillor."While Mrs May finished strongly ndash telling how Labour had made "Derek Hatton a hero and Churchhill a villain" and saying "Attlee and Bevin would be spinning in their graves" ndash it would be hard to pick a victor from todayrsquos clash.Scratch beneath the surface and there are two party leaders refusing to acknowledge crisis in their ranks. title: scotland-leading-the-way-in-tackling-marine-litter-says-nicola-sturgeon
story: The First Minister addressed international delegates attending Scotlandrsquos International Marine Conference in Glasgow.She revealed a pound, campaign to promote the use of re-usable sanitary products, which will reduce more than  billion pieces of sanitary waste disposed of every year.Read more:Take action on plasticThe funding is made up of Scottish Government funding andZero Waste Scotlandrsquos Resource Efficient Circular Economy Accelerator Programme, which is funded by the European Regional Development Fund .The Scottish Government is also expected to publish proposals in the coming weeks to make it an offence to throw litter overboard from all Scottish fishing vessels while at sea.It is also the first in the UK to commit to a ban on plastic stemmed cotton buds.The reveal comes after the Isle of Arran was named Scotlands first plastic-free community by Surfers Against Sewage.Read more:Isle of Arran is Scotlands first plastic-free communityThe First Minister said: "Scotland continues to lead the way in protecting our marine environments and the size of Scotlandrsquos marine protected area is testament to our commitment to protecting important habitats and species."This new campaign to promote re-usable sanitary products expands our existing efforts to tackle the problem of single use plastic."Following the successful introduction of legislation to ban plastic microbeads in rinse-off personal care products, we are the first in the UK to commit to a ban on plastic stemmed cotton buds."It is also important we tackle the smaller, but not insignicant, proportion of litter which comes from our marine industries."Our paper on the future of fisheries management will seek views on how we can ensure the fishing sector play their part in protecting the marine environment.

title: wacky-races-come-to-scottish-ski-slopes-for-first-time
story: For a decade the Red Bull Homerun, despite a dramatic pile-up in Sweden in , has lured daredevils from around the world.Next month it will come to Scotland for the first time, with  adrenaline junkies tearing down the Glencoe Mountain Resort.The race begins with competitors making a Le-Mans style mass sprint to grab their skis and snowboards, before clipping in for a top-to-bottom downwards dash.Among those taking part will be one of Britainrsquos top freeskiers Paddy Graham, who will put personal pride at stake.The Red Bull athlete said: ldquoPersonally, Irsquove never prepared for any kind of race as a freestyle skier or had to work on a sprinting technique, but thatrsquos just one of the things that makes the Red Bull Homerun stand out, being my first!ldquoI know Irsquoll have  other people trying to beat me, so Irsquoll be doing everything possible to make sure Irsquom the quickest out of the blocks come race day.ldquoThis is a unique race and Glencoe is the perfect place to host the UKrsquos first edition of the Red Bull Homerun, I canrsquot wait to test out my technique.The event is open to all intermediate skiers and snowboarders over the age of . The fastest skiers and snowboarders across the line, both male and female, will be crowned winners.Mr Graham will be hoping the weather changes. There is not, currently, enough snow in Glencoe for serious downhill skiing.The Homerum has been referred to as a ldquonutty race with the  crash in Are, Sweden, - in which no-one was hurt - described as ldquomayhem. The winner lost her poles and had to skate to victory after three skiers collided on a bend and many other racers crashed in to them.Shortly after the event, all competitors will enjoy an unbeatable apregraves-ski party at the bottom of the mountain, said organisers.Free coach transport from Glasgow and Edinburgh will be provided for any competitors travelling to the event from Scotlandrsquos two biggest cities.Red Bull Homerun will take place on Wednesday th March in Glencoe with the race set to get under way at pm. There are still places open for both competitors and spectators.

Many donrsquot knowitrsquos best to claim from your insurer, or from the council.She added: ldquoThe number of potholes reported in the UK has increased by  per cent in the last year, and itrsquos a battle councils continue to fight.ldquoIf motorists come across a pothole they should report it to their local authority before it gets any worse.Scottish Tory transport spokesman Jamie Greene said: ldquoThis shows again that Scots are driving and cycling on roads that are dangerous and deteriorating.ldquoThe Scottish Conservatives have committed to a poundm pothole fund that would enable local authorities to access the funds they need to fix our roads.ldquoThe SNPrsquos failure to fix our roads is damaging our economy, endangering our road users and the potholes are only getting bigger.More than two fthsof motorists in Scotland say they have had their car damaged by a pothole in the past, according to Confused.Bill Liddle, service manager at Fe Council, said it had provided ldquosustained capital investment in road conditions, with an extra poundm budget available for carriageway works over the last ten years.He said: ldquoIn addition, the number of potholes in Fe has dropped from around , a year to ,. In the face of budget restrictions, this is a success story.ldquoThe majority of potholes are actually reported by our own inspectors and most of those reported to us by the public will already have been identied and programmed for repair.He said the council aimed to repair potholes within five working days of a defect being reported.

Connelly has worked in traffic control since  so theres not much he hasnt seen. The Beast from the East brought the worst weather conditions hes encountered during his many years of service. The team is both proactive and reactive in its mission to keep Scotland’s roads moving – planning for issues it can see coming and responding quickly to those that it can’t.Partnerships play an essential role in the day-to-day operations here.For example, we’re sitting in the resilience room where Transport Scotland, the Scottish Government agency which oversees our transport industry, meets during major crises, such as the Beast from the East.It is here, too, where action plans are drawn up to cope with major events on the annual calendar or roadworks on vital routes.A Police Scotland officer is based in the centre at peak times, along with Traffic Scotland’s media officers who Tweet updates throughout the day and INRIX, a radio team which transmits travel updates, both on the website and to most of our radio stations.From September to April, a MET office employee is also based in the centre.But Traffic Scotland has many more partners behind the scenes too.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fetoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It looks likely that the council will raise the areas Council Tax rates by three per cent"  Counterfeit cash alert after incidents reported in Fe viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "FFPL | Article Teaser"Stein explained: “We work closely with event organisers to ensure people get to the Open or Royal Highland Show with as little disruption as possible, particularly when two major events are on at the same time.“We also work with the road operating companies, Freight Haulage Association and public transport providers, such as Abellio Scotrail. We co-ordinate road and rail works to minimise the impact for commuters and the Scottish economy.”With all of the country’s roadside SOS calls also being answered at the centre, there are few down times.It’s a round-the-clock job and often a tough one, with operators witnessing incidents that take a toll.Even Stein, despite his many years in the job, isn’t immune.He explained: “Operators can take a call from someone saying they’re going to jump off the Erskine Bridge, pan the camera round and see them jumping. That can really stay with someone.“One that sticks in my mind was an accident at Charing Cross in Glasgow.“The car was a mess and as we panned the camera round we saw a child’s car seat, empty, on the road.“The room fell quiet but nothing was said. Later on, the police told us there were no fatalities and no children had been hurt – the sense of relief here was amazing.”Staff have access to counselling, should they need it as a result of anything they’ve witnessed.But you get the sense of a camaraderie among the team too which undoubtedly helps get them through the tough days.Last February and March, the Beast from the East proved a real challenge – some operators didn’t make it home for days, while others couldn’t make it in.Stein was at the helm through it all, steering the ship through the worst road conditions witnessed in Scotland in a generation.He said: “It was pretty bad in  but the Beast from the East is the worst weather I’ve ever experienced.“Usually, we can marshall maintenance teams and gritters from one part of the country to help in other areas hit by severe weather. That just wasn’t possible. “I was camped out here for five days, as was Humza Yousaf, the then transport minister. The operators couldn’t get home either so they just got on with the job, like they always do.“It was the first red weather warning in Scotland – everyone learned from it.”A Hilltip Icestriker from Finland is now being trialled on the M to ensure recovery teams can access incidents and an electric powered spreader has been deployed on the M.As for daily operations, the public also has an important role to play.“We have just over  CCTV cameras on km of roads,” said Stein. “It’s not a lot to cover such a large area.“So the public are often our eyes and ears, alerting us to breakdowns so we can send out a recovery team.“We get a lot of thank you letters as a result.”Those worried about big brother watching need not fear either.Stein added: “We don’t record number plates or incidents, unless the police ask us to.“So while we get a lot of requests, we can’t help solicitors looking for accident recordings – we don’t have them.”Crossing over the Forth is now far more reliableTraffic Scotland’s National Control Centre was opened on April , , by then depute first minister Nicola Sturgeon. Also used as a contact and education centre for pupils to find out more about the £. billion Queensferry Crossing, thousands of children visited to get a bird’s eye view as the project unfolded. At . miles , it is the longest bridge of its type in the world and also the tallest, towering mhigh. But has it eased congestion for those travelling along the east coast artery between Fe and Edinburgh According to Traffic Scotland statistics, the crossing is very much doing the job it was intended for.Since September , there have been  occasions when the Forth Road Bridge would have been closed to high-sided vehicles due to high winds.Wind shielding on the new crossing enabled it to remain open, affording far more reliability for commuters and hauliers who regularly use it.The hard shoulder on the new bridge also means there are no longer lane closuresvehicles breakdown along its span.Stein said: “The crossing’s improved reliability is delivering benefits not only for commuters but for businesses and the wider Scottish economy too.”

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. title: driving voucher win for inverurie pupil
story: An Inverurie Academy pupil will soon be ready to take on the roads safely thanks to a prize from the British Transport Police.On Friday, November  last year British Transport Police officer Derek Jackson attended the school to give a Level Crossing presentation to th and th year pupils.The presentation aimed to highlight and promote safe driving standards to new and learning drivers whilst using a level crossing.After the presentation Derek handed out a quiz relating to driving standards and legislation with a top prize on offer.S pupil Shaun McCabe won and received a £ Red Driving School voucher.The prize was kindly sponsored by Network Rail.Derek presented Shaun with his prize on Wednesday, February , alongside Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett and Lauren McCreedy, Mobile Operations Manager of Network Rail.Speaking to the Herald Shaun said he was “chuffed” to win the prize, and said he would put it towards Pass Plus, a training course that helps new drivers to improve their skills and drive more safely.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Man suffers serious injuries following crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: motorists urged to drive with caution on awpr
story: Road users are being encouraged to drive with extreme caution on all north east roads while they become accustomed to a new section of the A.The new section of road, around . miles long, will link the southern Craibstone to Stonehaven and Charleston section with the Parkhill to Blackdog section in the north from early tomorrow morning .The Craibstone, Parkhill and Kingswells NorthJunctions will be fully opened to traffic once signs have been uncovered, road marking works completed and temporary traffic management measures removed.The link road connecting the CC Chapel of Stoneywood to Craibstone Junction will also be opened to use, allowing work to begin on permanently closing its junction with the A.Douglas Laird, project manager for the AWPR B-T project at Transport Scotland, said: “This new section of road between Craibstone and Parkhill will bring a range of benefits to road users, including reduced congestion, improved journey time reliability and enhanced safety.“However, we would like to remind road users to drive with caution for their own safety and to consider the safety of other road users as there are a number of changes to road layout to become accustomed to. There may be a degree of uncertainty amongst some drivers and all drivers should be prepared to react appropriately to ensure journeys can be completed safely.“We also kindly request that road users observe all signage and mody their driving accordingly to suit the prevailing road and weather conditions, such as low sun or rain.”Police Scotland Chief Inspector Stewart Mackie, who is responsible for Road Policing in the North added: “It is good to see the last section of the AWPR now opening."The Stonehaven to Craibstone section had a huge impact on traffic levels in the city and the final section will further improve journey times in and around Aberdeen.“As with previous sections, I would urge motorists to take time to familiarise themselves with the layout. The final section is elevated and provides good views across the airport and north of the city.I would urge motorist to remain focused on the road ahead and not be distracted."The bypass is designed to the highest safety standards and as such we would hope that we see a reduction in casualties and collisions in and around Aberdeen as a result."North Safety Camera Unit Area Manager, Arron Duncan said: “Working to support our police colleagues, we will continue to carry out highly visible mobile enforcement on the now completed AWPR."By carrying out this period of short term deployment we aim to positively remind motorists of their speed limits and help make the AWPR a safe and enjoyable route.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Head along to Willows for the festival - and meet the animals at the sanctuary too"  Animal sanctuary to host special event viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: research to focus on rural transport
story: Researchers are heading to Inverurie to explore new transport services for local-residents.Following a Scottish Rural Transport Conference held in Inverness in September , the Transport Systems Catapult will be working in partnership with local business JLM and Mobility Lab UK, on a new accessible transport service for the community.Transport Services in rural areas require a dferent approach to that seen in big towns and cities, one that is based on the needs of communities who depend on transport services for everyday le. Accessible and affordable transport is a leline for many rural residents, connecting people to opportunities for socialising, working, learning and healthcare. The research in Inverurie will seek to understand the needs of the community in a rural Scottish location, including residents and local businesses and see how current transport services are meeting those needs.Findings will be used to develop and design new services that can be trialled in rural areas.Jenny Milne, from JLM said: “This project provides a great opportunity to understand the challenges travelling to, in and around Inverurie. By working with the community, it will help to understand what transport services are needed, and what steps can then be taken to improve existing routes around the town. “The project also hopes to engage the villages around Inverurie.“By using focus groups and asking the local community about their ideas, it will help to shape rural transport to the benefit of those living in the area.”The project also has support from Colin Clark, Scottish Conservative MP for Gordon: “I would urge local residents and businesses in the Inverurie area to take part in this project and make their views known.“Many people depend upon public transport in rural areas – to get to work, to socialise or to keep appointments at local GP and dental surgeries.“We are fortunate in Inverurie to have a train station connecting the town with Aberdeen and Inverness and there has recently been major investment in the line. “However, in more remote parts of Aberdeenshire, public transport is less reliable and frequent. The results of this research will help inform future policy – and hopefully lead to improvements”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Council leader Jim Gford said it had been the hardest budget to set"  Council tax rise and job cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: uryside park secures european funding
story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me.
